At that time, the remarks made by the Tesla CEO triggered a sharp drop in Bitcoin’s price and the debates over crypto’s environmental footprint intensified.However, now Musk appears to be aligning with a growing narrative that Bitcoin’s proof-of-work model, while energy-intensive, offers a transparent and tamper-proof system that distinguishes it from fiat currencies and other digital assets.An X user asked shared a post on the social media platform which reads, “They money is not the problem: AI is the new global arms race, and apex will eventually be funded by governments (US and China.If you want to know why gold/silver/bitcoin is soaring, it’s the ‘debasement’ to fund the AI arms race. But you can’t print energy.”Responding to the post, Musk said, “True. That is why Bitcoin is based on energy: you can issue fake fiat currency, and every government in history has done so, but it is impossible to fake energy.”Elon Musk’s post came in response to a broader discussion about government funding the AI arms race by printing money. Some argue that inflating the value of assets such as gold, silver and Bitcoin. By emphasizing Bitcoin’s energy cost, Musk is reinforcing the idea that its value is rooted in physical reality, unlike currencies that can be created at will.Musk’s endorsement comes at a time when Bitcoin is gaining renewed attention, particularly as former President Donald Trump now in his second term has voiced support for the cryptocurrency.
Article Summary: Elon Musk has reversed his stance on Bitcoin, calling its energy-based foundation a key reason for its long-term value. Musk’s latest comments mark a significant shift from his 2021 stance, when he suspended Bitcoin payments for Tesla vehicles over conversion about fossil fuel usage.

Article Title: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos’ stake drops to 9%: How his ownership in Amazon declined over years
Article Text:
File photo: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos

Bezos’s ownership in Amazon over the years





Amazon founder Jeff Bezos ’ ownership in the e-commerce platform has declined to 9%, following a series of stock sales over the past years. In a new filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, the tech billionaire now holds 964.3 million shares of Amazon with sole voting power, and has the authority to dispose of around 883.3 million shares.The latest disclosure comes after Bezos announced plans to sell 25 million Amazon shares through May 2026 earlier this year. As per the SEC filings, he has also made several donations to nonprofit organizations.Bezos’ shareholding has steadily declined over the years — from more than 43% when Amazon went public in 1997, to 14.1% when he stepped down as CEO in 2021. In the past two years, Jeff Bezos has sold around $4.8 billion worth of the company’s stocks.In November last year, Jeff Bezos owned over 1 billion shares, or 10.1% of the company, with the right to sell about 927.5 million of them. According to Amazon’s annual proxy filing, his stake later dropped to 9.6% in February this year.In July, he offloaded approximately $737 million worth of Amazon stock. In the same month, he sold another 6.6 million shares of the company. The transaction took place on July 21 and 22. The sale was executed under the prearranged trading plan known as Rule 10b5-1.Apart from Amazon, Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post and Blue Origin, his space technology company. His net worth currently stands at $229.7 billion, according to Forbes, making him the world’s fourth richest person.
Article Summary: Bezos’ shareholding has steadily declined over the years — from more than 43% when Amazon went public in 1997, to 14.1% when he stepped down as CEO in 2021. In the past two years, Jeff Bezos has sold around $4.8 billion worth of the company’s stocks.

Article Title: Airtel and IBM Partner to deliver AI-optimized hybrid cloud in India
Article Text: Airtel has partnered with IBM to enhance its Cloud platform, offering AI-ready, secure, and scalable solutions for regulated industries. The collaboration integrates IBM's advanced infrastructure and software, including IBM Power11 servers, to provide as-a-Service offerings for mission-critical applications. This move expands Airtel's cloud footprint and aims to drive transformation in the era of AI for Indian enterprises.
Article Summary: Airtel has partnered with IBM to enhance its Cloud platform, offering AI-ready, secure, and scalable solutions for regulated industries. The collaboration integrates IBM's advanced infrastructure and software, including IBM Power11 servers. This move expands Airtel's cloud footprint and aims to drive transformation in the era of AI for Indian enterprises.

Article Title: China issues statement on American technology company it 'punished' on the day Donald Trump announced 100% extra tariff on China
Article Text:
Rising US-China trade tensions on Soyabean and more ...





China broke its silence on the American technology giant Qualcomm that had faced action from Chinese authorities hours before the US President announced his threat to impose 100% extra tariff on China, starting November 1. On October 10, China’s market regulator State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) launched an anti-monopoly investigation into US semiconductor giant Qualcomm for failing to report its acquisition of Israeli chip designer Autotalks, completed in June 2025. Trump's angry social media post on extra 100% tariff on China came the same day. The US president's post followed a string of tit-for-tat moves by US and China as Presidents Xi Jinping and Donald Trump seemingly look for leverage before a key meeting to discuss trade and other issues.Commenting on probe into Qualcomm, China's market regulator said that the US company has admitted that it had not informed Chinese authorities when it completed its acquisition of Israel's Autotalks in June 2025. The agency said that it had informed Qualcomm in March 2024 that the deal requires approval by the regulator, and the Qualcomm in the same month notified SAMR that it wouldn't pursue further. However, Qualcomm in June this year completed the deal without informing the authority, the regulator said, adding Qualcomm "acknowledged above facts", based on which Beijing launched the antitrust probe.Last week, Beijing’s Transport Ministry announced on October 10 that it will begin collecting fees on vessels owned by US companies and individuals, as well as those built in America, starting Oct. 14. The move coincides with the date Washington plans to impose new charges on large Chinese ships calling at US ports.Additionally, China tightened export controls on rare earths and other critical materials this week and halted US soybean purchases, moves seen as targeting American industries and communities that supported President Donald Trump in the 2024 election.President Donald Trump on Tuesday, October 14, said that his administration is considering “terminating business with China having to do with Cooking Oil” in retaliation for Beijing refusing to buy US soybeans. China has been the top buyer of U.S. soybeans by far, but it has not bought a single American soybean in months amid an ongoing trade war.
Article Summary: China's market regulator launched an anti-monopoly investigation into US semiconductor giant Qualcomm for failing to report its acquisition of Israeli chip designer Autotalks in June 2025. China's Transport Ministry announced on October 10 that it will begin collecting fees on vessels owned by US companies and individuals, as well as those built in America.
